meanings.def: a strong shoe that covers the foot and ankle and often the lower part of the leg
examples: a pair of heavy walking boots
a pair of black leather boots

meanings.def: the space at the back of a car that you put bags, cases, etc. in
examples: I'll put the luggage in the boot.
What have you got in the boot?
He gave the ball a tremendous boot.

meanings.def: a device that is attached to the wheel of a car that has been parked illegally, so that it cannot be driven away
to be told that you must leave your job or that a relationship you are having with somebody is over
examples: He should have been given the boot years ago.

meanings.def: to be/become too proud of yourself; to behave as if you are more important than you really are
used to say that a situation has changed so that somebody now has power or authority over the person who used to have power or authority over them
used to invite somebody to take as much as they like of something such as food, drink, etc; help yourself
to do somebody’s job in an acceptable way when they are not there
to show too much respect for somebody in authority because you want to please them
to kick somebody very hard, especially when they are on the ground
to attack somebody by criticizing them when they are in a difficult situation
examples: I wonder if the press will put the boot in?

meanings.def: to be very frightened or nervous
used to add a comment to something that you have said
examples: He was a vegetarian, and a fussy one to boot.

meanings.def: very strong and able to deal successfully with difficult conditions or situations
examples: She’s almost 90 but she’s still as tough as old boots.

idioms.idiom: be/get too big for your boots
idioms.def: to be/become too proud of yourself; to behave as if you are more important than you really are

to do somebody’s job in an acceptable way when they are not there

idioms.def: to be very frightened or nervous
used to add a comment to something that you have said
examples: He was a vegetarian, and a fussy one to boot.

idioms.idiom: (as) tough as old boots | (as) tough as nails
idioms.def: very strong and able to deal successfully with difficult conditions or situations
examples: She’s almost 90 but she’s still as tough as old boots.

meanings.def: to kick somebody/something hard with your foot
examples: He booted the ball clear of the goal.

meanings.def: to prepare a computer for use by loading its operating system; to be prepared in this way
if you or your car is booted, a piece of equipment is fixed to the car’s wheel so that you cannot drive it away, usually because the car is illegally parked
